item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The next phase of the Trump administration’s escalating pressure campaign on the government of President Nicolás Maduro could be sabotage or some sort of cyber, psychological or information operations.

item.title: Ecuador Votes ‘No’ to Hosting U.S. Military Base
item.description: A vote on Sunday rejected the expansion of a foreign military presence. It came as the U.S. military’s campaign in waters near Latin America has been roiling the region.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Gerardo Menoscal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Celebrations after the results of a constitutional referendum in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Team Calls Maduro a ‘Cartel’ Boss. That Word Doesn’t Mean What You Think.
item.description: Venezuelans coined a figure of speech for the phenomenon of generals corrupted by drug money: “Cartel de los Soles.” Then the United States started talking about it as a literal organization.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump Treasury Department officially labeled Cartel de los Soles a global terrorist entity in July.

item.title: U.S. Military Threat Puts Spotlight on Venezuela’s Allies
item.description: American adversaries are unlikely to help President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela fend off a concerted attack. But they have made toppling him harder.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Reuters
item.media:description: A Russian fighter jet and rocket launchers on display in San Carlos del Meta, Venezuela.

item.title: House Democrats Press for Vote to Bar Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The effort would invoke the War Powers Act, which expedites action on measures limiting the president’s war-making authority. It faces long odds in the G.O.P.-led House.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Gregory Meeks of New York, the top Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee, is leading the effort in the House.

item.title: Trump Gives Mixed Messages About Military Action Against Venezuela
item.description: President Trump said that he was open to talking with President Nicolás Maduro but that the United States has “to take care of Venezuela” as the U.S. builds a military force in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Monday. Last month, Mr. Trump called off efforts to reach a diplomatic agreement with Venezuela, but the president has raised the possibility of renewed engagement.

item.title: Worker Error Is Faulted After Israeli-Born Canadian Hits Passport Snag
item.description: A student in Montreal, who was born in Kfar Saba, Israel, said she was initially told she could not list Israel as her birth country on her passport.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: 2 Charged in Over 300 Thefts at Mausoleums in Toronto Area
item.description: The thefts took place during the daytime when the pair would enter mausoleums to swipe necklaces and other jewelry from remains, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: High Beef Prices? Trump Official Blames Biden and Migrants.
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said migrants were bringing sick cows across the border, snarling beef supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.media:description: For President Trump, who served fast food sandwiches to the Clemson University football team during its 2019 visit to the White House, few meals hit closer to home than hamburgers.

item.title: We Can Now Track Individual Monarch Butterflies. It’s a Revelation.
item.description: Scientists used tiny new sensors to follow the insects on journeys that take thousands of miles to their winter colonies in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Dan Fagin and Jonathan Corum
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: The ‘Donroe Doctrine’: Trump’s Bid to Control the Western Hemisphere
item.description: President Trump has tightened the U.S. grip on the Americas by rewarding allies and punishing rivals. That has upended the region’s politics.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump aboard Air Force One on Friday. His administration has shown its interest in stronger control of Latin America, which promises major benefits.

item.title: Hydropower Is Getting Less Reliable as the World Needs More Energy
item.description: Demand for power is growing fast, but hydro plants, the oldest source of clean energy, are struggling because of droughts, floods and other extreme weather linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Latest U.S. Strike on Boat in Pacific Kills 3, Southern Command Says
item.description: The United States has carried out at least 21 strikes on boats the Trump administration accuses of smuggling drugs, killing at least 83 people.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jonathan Klein/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Gerald R. Ford, the largest and most advanced U.S. aircraft carrier, engaging in NATO exercises in the North Sea in September. On Sunday, the U.S. Southern Command said the vessel had arrived in the Caribbean.

item.title: Trump-Style Candidate Heads to Runoff in Chile’s Election
item.description: The conservative José Antonio Kast will face Jeannette Jara, a Communist Party member, in a vote next month.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett
item.media:credit: Pablo Sanhueza/Reuters & Marvin Recinos/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: UN Climate Summit in Brazil Brings Tourism and Change to Belém’s Ver-o-Peso Market
item.description: A market central to a Brazilian port city’s culture and cuisine got a makeover for the U.N. Climate Change Conference. The results have thrilled some but angered others.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors in the Ver-o-Peso market serving fish and açaí to customers at newly renovated booths in the food sector in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: Protesters Rage Against Mexico’s Government Over Corruption and Violence
item.description: Members of Mexico’s Gen Z, as well as older protesters, demonstrated on Saturday in the wake of a high-profile assassination and rising anger over persistent violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Fred Ramos
item.media:description: Protesters and police clashed in Mexico City on Saturday.

item.title: 4 Dead After Suspected Migrant Boat Overturns Near a San Diego Area Beach
item.description: The boat capsized off the coast, officials said. Four people were taken to a hospital and one person was taken into custody.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Mike Blake/Reuters
item.media:description: Four people were dead after a boat capsized off the coast of Imperial Beach in San Diego County, Calif. A search was underway, officials said.

item.title: Man Who Stuffed Parakeets in His Pants Faces Smuggling Charge
item.description: The man was found with the heavily sedated birds in his underwear as he crossed the border from Mexico in late October, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz

item.title: Vatican to Return Indigenous Cultural Items to Canada Taken a Century Ago
item.description: Dozen of pieces used in a 1925 exhibition, including a whale-hunting kayak, will be returned to Canada early next month.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indigenous chiefs in Alberta during Pope Francis’ visit to Canada in 2022.

item.title: A Challenge to Canada’s Official Policy That the U.S. Is Safe for Migrants
item.description: A former Liberal immigration minister said that Canada should drop an agreement that allows it to return asylum seekers who enter from the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcos Jesús Basulto Salinas at home in Venezuela with his son after a four-month imprisonment in El Salvador.

item.title: What Happened to Gabriel Boric’s Leftist Promises for Chile?
item.description: When he was elected four years ago, President Gabriel Boric of Chile carried ambitious promises and new energy. Then reality kicked in.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gabriel Boric of Chile is not eligible for re-election this year because of term limits.

item.title: Bad Bunny Tops the Latin Grammys: 8 Key Moments From the Show
item.description: The multicultural awards ceremony hinted at rediscovered roots and ways forward as Karol G, Paloma Morphy and Liniker also earned big wins.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters
item.media:description: Bad Bunny won five trophies at the 26th annual Latin Grammys in Las Vegas on Thursday night.

item.title: Indigenous People Take the Stage at COP30 Climate Talks in Belém, Brazil
item.description: This summit is unlike any of its predecessors in at least one significant way: The Indigenous presence is palpable and strong.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta, Brad Plumer and David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Mauro Pimentel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Indigenous rights demonstration on Thursday in Belém, Brazil. The snake in the background was a prop with a meaning.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa Leaves Behind a Staggering Homelessness Toll in Jamaica
item.description: Two weeks after Hurricane Melissa wrecked western Jamaica, officials are beginning to grapple with the challenge of trying to find housing for thousands of families.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Erin Schaff

item.title: Mexico City Loves Street Food. Its Sewer System Does Not.
item.description: The worst rainy season in decades caused flooding around much of the city. Fat from its many taco shops, restaurants and markets was a major reason for blocked drains, officials say.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas

item.title: Justice Dept. Memo Blessing Boat Strikes Is Said to Rely on Trump’s Claims About Cartels
item.description: Accounts of a secret Justice Department memo offer a window into how administration lawyers approved the president’s desired course of action.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has insisted that its boat strikes are lawful, telling Congress in September that Mr. Trump had “determined” that the United States was in a noninternational armed conflict.

item.title: Carney Accelerates Economic Plan for Canada to Rely Less on U.S. Amid Trade War
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney fast-tracked mines and other natural resource projects to the dismay of some Indigenous groups and many environmentalists.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada speaking at Parliament last week.

item.title: U.S. Strike Kills 4 on Boat Trump Says Was Smuggling Drugs
item.description: The strike in the Caribbean brings the death toll in the Trump administration’s lethal campaign to 80 since early September.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: The administration said U.S. strikes on boats were lawful because President Trump had “determined” that the United States is in a formal armed conflict with drug cartels.

item.title: Family of Fisherman Killed in U.S. Military Strike Says It Wants Justice
item.description: Colombia was a top U.S. ally in Latin America until the Trump administration began deadly strikes in international waters. Now, one family wants justice.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Federico Rios
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fishermen arriving back at the beach at the end of the day in Santa Marta, Colombia.

item.title: An Ontario Man Took a Bus for a Joyride. Turns Out, He’s Not a Bad Driver.
item.description: The incident in Hamilton, Ontario, ended safely with an arrest and no injuries (and all fares paid).
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Sevenstock Studio/Shutterstock
item.media:description: A bus in Hamilton like the one taken for a joyride this week.

item.title: Canada-U.S. Travel Drops for 10th Month Amid Trump Tariff Tensions
item.description: The drop has been reflected in air and car travel, according to Canadian statistics. Tensions over tariffs placed by the Trump administration spurred calls for Canadians to spend their money at home.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Peace Bridge port of entry between Canada and the United States, in Fort Erie, Ontario, in September.

item.title: Rubio Shrugs Off Allies’ Concerns Over U.S. Drug Strikes
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said no one raised the Caribbean military operation in closed-door meetings at a G7 summit. But ministers from France and the European Union publicly called them unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mandel Ngan
item.media:description: Marco Rubio, speaking after the G7 foreign ministers meeting, said many of the drug shipments targeted by the U.S. military are bound for Europe “so maybe they should be thanking us.”

item.title: How to See the Northern Lights on Wednesday
item.description: A geomagnetic storm made the aurora borealis visible across a swath of the United States again on Wednesday, illuminating the skies as far south as Arizona.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Matterhorn Ski Paradise and Feratel/UGC, via Reuters
item.media:description: The northern lights shine in the night sky in Valtournenche, Italy, on Wednesday.

item.title: Gustavo Petro, the Rebel Turned President Willing to Take on Trump
item.description: From his guerrilla roots, Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, has long embraced a confrontational style. Now, he has incurred President Trump’s wrath and is facing political fallout at home.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro speaking last week in Bogota, Colombia.

item.title: Missing at U.N.’s Climate Meeting: American Executives
item.description: Many business leaders are skipping the annual United Nations climate summit in Belém, Brazil, or are attending events in other cities.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Fernando Llano/Associated Press
item.media:description: Officials from around the world are attending the U.N. climate summit in Belém, Brazil, this week, but U.S. government and business leaders are not among them.

item.title: A Look Into the Early Days of Migrant Detentions at Guantánamo
item.description: Government employees distributed Bibles and prepared materials “commonly used in Hinduism, Sikhism and Rastafarianism,” according to emails.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. forces put up a tent city near the airfield at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, at the beginning of the year to house thousands of migrants who were designated for deportation. None were ever held there.
